messageBody:
I agree with Johannes about the service method. Take a peek at the source code
for HttpServlet and you will find that you really don't have to overwrite the
service method for servlets that subclass HttpServlet. You will notice that the
service method in HttpServlet handles the HTTP 1.1 calls done to it (POST, GET,
DELETE,etc). That said if you want to test the outcome of you get() and post()
then use httpunit ( http://httpunit.sourceforge.net/ ) to test those methods.
The reason why is that conceptually you are actually doing functional testing
(acceptance testing in XP parlance) on the servlet.

For testing the individual methods of the servlet then use j2eeunit. This way
you are assured that the environment that contains your servlet is the
appropiate one this means that all calls to methods that may have some unknown
dependency with the servlet container will be appropiately enforced. I would
recommend starting with the public methods that return a value. This is an easy
of mastering j2eeunit. Assert that your values returned are not null and that
they are what you expect from the method. Remember to properly set any
parameters in the request so as to make sure that the servlet is in the
appropiate state when you test.

If you want to do unit testing on the private methods then you will run into
problems since the family of junit pacakges and extensions can only easily
access public methods OR protected method IF the testCase is in the same
package as the class to test. There are other ways of testing private methods
like using inner classes but for now the fastest and easiest way is to convert
the private methods to protected and write the test for them.

Start here. You will soon be asking yourself other questions about unit testing
but if you do the above then you should be ready to start thinking about
refactoring this class and you will be able to start thinking of the answers to
the questions that will come up.

Caveat : write test, write code, run test, repeat.

Happy hacking

-H
